ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CHILD CARE CENTRES


    1. Mr Yeo Toon Chia: To ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Community Development how many child care centres will be set up for the financial year 1985/86; where will they be located; what will be their capacity; and what will be the rates of charges.

Column: 1258



     Mr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Question No. 1, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs and Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Community Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    It is projected that a total of 40 child care centres will be set up this year providing a

Column: 1259

capacity of 2,200. The centres will be managed by the People's Association, the NTUC, by employers, voluntary organizations as well as by the Ministry of Community Development and private operators. These 40 child care centres will bring the total capacity of child care places to 5,800 by the end of fiscal year 1985.

    Of the 40 child care centres, 14 will be in work places, the remaining will be in HDB estates, community centres and private residential estates. The Government subsidizes child care centres run by the NTUC, by the PA and other organizations which adopt the NTUC and PA rates of charges as well as the standard of child care. The fees range from $150 to $250, depending on the income of parents.

    For the private child care centres, the fees will vary according to the services provided, and they may vary from $250 to $350.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): May I ask the Minister of State whether these child care centres are being provided for the highly paid people in our society or for the working class people?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, the child care centres are provided for every Singaporean who wants to use the service. There is no distinction between whether they are highly paid or lowly paid. The fee structure, however, distinguishes those families whose combined income is lower and therefore will pay less, from those families whose combined income is high, and therefore pay more.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does his Ministry really expect a working class family to be able to afford $150?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, a family with a combined income of $1,450 can afford the $150 child care fee.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know how many working class families have a combined income of $1,450?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, this requires a study to be made.

     Mr Speaker: Yes, it is not relevant to the question asked.

KIDNAP FOR RANSOM CASES


    2. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law whether there is a rise in the number of reported kidnap for ransom cases in Singapore in the last few years, and, if so, what actions have been taken to curb this type of crime.

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Second Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the last 10 years there were only three cases of kidnapping for ransom. One was in 1977, another in 1979, and the last one was reported in February this year. There is therefore no significant rise in the number of such reported cases. All the three cases have been solved with the arrest of the kidnappers. The recent case reported in February, 1985, was alleged to have been committed by someone known to the victim's family, and not by any organized gang of kidnappers.

    Sir, the law provides severe penalties for this offence. Under the provisions of the Kidnapping Act, a person convicted of kidnapping for ransom shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life and, if not sentenced to death, shall also be liable to caning. The Police have been effective in dealing with such cases, which are investigated by the Special Investigations Section of the CID which has the necessary expertise to deal with delicate and complex investigations.

    The record shows that all 34 cases reponed to the Police since 1959 have been solved. Sir, the punishments provided by the Kidnapping Act and the success of the Police in dealing with these cases have had the desired deterrent effect.

LOCAL INDUSTRIES AND MULTINATIONAL CORPORATIONS
(Effects of economic slowdown)


    3. Dr Augustine H.H. Tan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the current economic slowdown has hit local industries more than large multinational corporations; how many local companies in manufacturing closed down

Column: 1261

last year; how many workers have lost their jobs; and what assistance the Government is providing to our local industries.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1984, 66 manufacturing companies were dissolved. All these 66 were local. 81 manufacturing companies went into liquidation. Only one of these was foreign. Sir, there were a total of 147 manufacturing companies which closed down in 1984, and this is equivalent to 29% of the total company closures of 505 during the year.

    However, this must be seen in the context of the total number of companies in Singapore which approximately now stand at 63,000.

    On the question of retrenchments, in 1984 3,487 workers in the manufacturing sector were retrenched, accounting for 75% of the total retrenchments in the country as a whole, 4,694. We do not believe that retrenchment is now a serious problem, as most of those retrenched workers have been able to find replacement jobs, as our labour market is still fairly tight. In fact, I would like to join my colleague, the Minister for Finance, in assuring the House that the economy is not in as bad a state as some Members and the press might think.

    While some companies have closed down, many more new companies have, in fact, been formed. In 1984, a total of 4,601 new companies were formed, against 505 closures. This includes the manufacturing and the non-manufacturing. Hence, there was a net increase of 4,096 new net company formations out of a total of 63,000 companies. This represents a growth in the company numbers rate of about 6.5%, which is in line with the growth of the economy.

    The birth and death of companies is part of the restructuring process and also the evolutionary process of a dynamic economy. It is something which, I think, we have to learn to accept. It is indeed painful for those which have to close down, but we must look at the net effect on the

Column: 1262

economy as a whole. To put it into perspective, in Japan last year, 19,000 companies closed down. Amongst them were large steel mills, shipyards, oil refineries, because they were also going through a major restructuring process of upgrading themselves. I do not think anyone can claim that Japan's economy is in difficulties or that it is not a dynamic economy.

    As for retrenchments, the picture is also not as gloomy as the press may sometimes paint it. As at 15th March 1985, 7,062 workers have been retrenched. For the first quarter of 1985 as a whole, we expect the total retrenchments to number around 1,000. In the last five years, for the period 1980 to 1984, the average number of retrenched workers in the first quarter of each year was about 1,300 so that the number of retrenchments expected in this first quarter is not out of the ordinary.

    I would just like, Mr Speaker, Sir, to urge that perhaps occasionally the press might wish to consider printing some of the positive aspects of our economy rather than concentrate entirely on company closures and retrenchments. We could do with a bit of light relief from time to time.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, coming back to the question of the Member for Whampoa, I would like to add that the Government does not find it necessary or desirable to provide financial support to companies facing winding-up action. However, the EDB has intervened in some cases to try and persuade banks to be more flexible in recalling their loans.

    On the subject, Mr Speaker, Sir, of help for local industries, the EDB whilst actively promoting foreign investments places particular emphasis on helping local entrepreneurs. The Board's overseas and home-based officers work together to arrange joint ventures with foreign companies for sub-contracts for our local industries. Assistance schemes available to foreign companies are also available to local industries. They include tax incentives, Interest Grant for Mechanization Scheme and the Training Grant Scheme. The latter two schemes are funded by the Skills Development Fund. These schemes have benefited our local industries tremendously. Over the last three years,

Column: 1263

more than half the tax incentives, like pioneer status, investment allowances and export incentives granted, were awarded to wholly local-owned or local-foreign joint venture companies.

    As for the Interest Grant for Mechanization Scheme, 69% of all grants or $33.7 million had been given to local companies as at 31st December, 1984. Local companies are also the major beneficiaries of the Training Grant Scheme. Of the $216 million of grants committed between 1980 and 1984, 65% were for local industries. In addition there were specific schemes which are specially designed to help small and medium-sized local companies. For example, the Small Industries Finance Scheme, Special Grants for Critical Supporting Industries, Product Development Assistance Scheme, Small Industry Technical Assistance Scheme, Development Consultancy Scheme and the Preferential Release of Skilled Workers from the EDB-Joint Industrial Training Centres. Details are given in the Annex (Cols. 1341 - 1342) which the Clerk has already distributed to Members.
Annex (Cols. 1341 - 1342)


    Mr Speaker, Sir, local industries are very important to our economic development. Their profits are retained in Singapore and accrued to our people. Hence, the Government has always been more generous in granting tax incentives and allocating specially-trained skilled workers to local industries. If need be, the Government will set up more incentive schemes to help local industries.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Minister seems to be implying that the press reports about bankruptcies and closures of companies have been a bit on the sensational side. Is he afraid that this may produce a panic situation?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not suggesting that the press has been deliberately playing up the bad aspects of Singapore's economy. I appreciate that from the press reporter's point of view it is easier to gather reports on retrenchments and company failures than to gather information on company openings and new employment opportunities created by new

Column: 1264

companies. I would merely ask them to try and present a more balanced view so that the world at large can understand that Singapore is not going down the tubes.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Minister mentioned that the EDB intervened in some cases to persuade the banks to be more flexible in recalling their loans. We all know that the EDB was set up to attract foreign investors to come to Singapore. So, were their efforts made largely on behalf of foreign companies or were some local companies involved as well?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the majority of these requests were in aid of local companies because, by and large, it is the smaller companies which are involved. The major multi-nationals normally do not require such assistance.

     Dr Augustine Tan: In looking at the Annex, while the various assistance schemes given to industries, both local and foreign, look good and helpful, one element seems to be missing, and that is, of marketing. What is the Government doing in this respect to help our industries in marketing?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Annex relates to schemes developed and administered by the EDB. We have a separate organization, the Trade Development Board, which specializes in marketing and the hon. Member for Chong Boon is, in fact, the Chairman of the Trade Development Board. This was set up about two years ago as a result of requests from the business community. It has expanded tremendously in the last two years and one of the areas where they are concentrating on, in fact, is marketing.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Sir, is the Hon. Minister aware that there is a distinction between companies which are formed and companies which actually commence business? If so, of the 4,601 new companies which were formed last year, how many have actually commenced business?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am well aware of this. I did mention in my

Column: 1265

response during the debate on the President's Speech that one has to be cautious about looking at statistics because a large number of companies formed need not necessarily have such business. We do not keep a day-to-day check on the number of companies which have gone into operation. So I cannot give an immediate answer. But the statistics are readily available. If the Member wishes to have this, we will provide it to him.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the recent Budget Address, the Finance Minister gave a number of significant concessions like the suspension of the Payroll Tax and the reduction of the Skills Development Fund.

     Mr Speaker: Dr Tan, where is your supplementary question?

     Dr Augustine Tan: I am coming to it, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: Come to it then.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Some of the comments by industrialists have been that these concessions have been too few and make a negligible impact so far as their costs are concerned.

     Mr Speaker: Your supplementary question, Dr Tan.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Yes. Can I have the comment or the view of the Minister on this?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: I am not entirely clear on the question, ie, whether the incentives were sufficient or there is a request for more of them.

     Dr Augustine Tan: More.

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: It is something which I cannot really answer on behalf of the Minister for Finance. It is fair to say that whatever one grants to business people would not be sufficient because if I were a businessman I think it would be foolish for me to say that I have had enough. Inevitably, whatever is requested would be insufficient from somebody's point of view. But I think the Minister for Finance would take this into consideration in the light of the actual circumstances.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1985 TO 31 ST MARCH, 1986



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [4th Allotted Day].

11.18 am

    Head U (cont) -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two amendments and I propose to take them one at a time. I propose to move first my amendment under Subhead UA-01 of the Main Estimates. I move, Mr Speaker, Sir,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead UA-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Mr Speaker, may I say that I am disappointed that the Prime Minister is not here this morning because I was hoping that he would answer this question that I have for him. All I wish to say is that I hope he was not exhausted by the long lesson he gave in history and arithmetic yesterday and that other pressing business keeps him from the House.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, my query this morning relates to the appointment of Political Secretary. There is a post in the Prime Minister's Office for one Political Secretary and I think there are such posts in one or two other ministries as well. This gentleman who currently fills the post of Political Secretary in the Prime Minister's Office, I believe, was appointed sometime last year. He was going to lead the assault on the ground that the PAP had lost in 1981. He was going to be the flag-bearer for the PAP into Anson and to give him more clout he was appointed Political Secretary to the Prime Minister. And no sooner was he appointed, he had cards printed with his photograph circulated to all the residents in Anson. "Here I come, Political Secretary to the Prime Minister." That, in the end, did not help the PAP or the gentleman in question.

    I am not here to talk about him and what he did but rather to query this provision for Political Secretary in the Budget. May I inquire from whoever is going to reply to

Column: 1267

this, where is the provision for the appointment of Political Secretaries? I have looked through the Constitution, Mr Speaker, Sir, and there is no provision in the Constitution for the appointment of Political Secretaries. I take it that "Political Secretary" is a political appointment and if it is a political appointment, one would find it in the Constitution. There is no provision in the Constitution for the appointment of Political Secretaries.

    I see that way back in 1959 the then Member for Farrer Park, who is now sitting on the High Court Bench, also asked about this and he pointed out that there was nothing in the Constitution about the appointment of Political Secretary. He said that the appointment of Political Secretary was something which was not known to the Constitution of Singapore. I would like to know where is the authority for this appointment of Political Secretary.

    If it is not a political appointment, it is then a Civil Service appointment. Is it a civil service appointment? If it is a Civil Service appointment, then what was a civil servant doing, contesting the elections for the PAP in the constituency of Anson? May we have clarification from whoever is going to reply on this too?

    Secondly, this gentleman who now occupies the post of Political Secretary in the Prime Minister's Office, I understand, is also currently the Assistant SecretaryGeneral, or is it Deputy Secretary-General, in the NTUC. May we know whether he is working full-time with the NTUC or whether he is working full-time in the Prime Minister's Office as Political Secretary? If he is working full-time with the NTUC, which I understood is the case, then how is he being paid out of public funds? I know about the symbiotic relationship between the NTUC and the Government. But it would be a complete violation of the Constitution, of the Finance Act, for the person who is working for the NTUC or any other organization to be paid out of public funds. I can only suggest that if that is the case, then whoever appointed him should be surcharged for the salaries that had been paid. I am surprised that the Auditor-General has not drawn attention to the salaries that have been paid to Political Secretaries in the past.

Column: 1268



    With that, I will sit down, Mr Speaker, Sir, but I would like to come back to the reply made by whoever replies.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not an expert on law and I am certainly not an expert on the Constitution of Singapore. But the Member for Anson is a lawyer and I believe he should know the Constitution much better than 1. I take it that he has gone through the Constitution and must have come across the clause wherein the appointment of Political Secretaries, Ministers and other office-bearers is specifically mentioned in the Constitution.

    The terms and conditions of appointment of Ministers, Political Secretaries and other office-bearers may not be mentioned in the Constitution. But I believe the Constitution expressly provided for the post of Political Secretary, and the appointment by the Prime Minister of Political Secretaries is perfectly in order. It is not a Civil Service appointment. It is a political appointment.

    What are the terms of the particular Political Secretary whom he mentioned is working in NTUC? I do not believe that there is any wrongdoing. If there is, I am sure the Auditor-General who audits our accounts properly would have pointed this out. Under the Constitution, I believe the Prime Minister has every right and authority to decide how his Political Secretary should work. If there is any abuse of public funds, as the Member for Anson seems to have alleged, we have the Public Accounts Committee. We have the Auditor-General, and he would have pointed this out to us. But he has not done so.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am not in the Public Accounts Committee.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: For good reasons.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, for good reasons.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: The AuditorGeneral and the Public Accounts Committee have been fearless in pointing out any infringement of any rules or laws in this Administration.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I have erred, I would be the first to withdraw

Column: 1269

my allegation. Would the First Deputy Prime Minister point to the Article in the Constitution of Singapore? I must have been blind when I went through this, because I cannot find it myself. But would he draw my attention to the Article in the Constitution which says that there shall be a Political Secretary appointed? I see under Article 25 that the President shall appoint as Prime Minister a Member of Parliament and he shall also appoint Ministers acting in accordance with the advice of the Prime Minister. That is Article 25 of the Constitution.
11.30 am

    If you move to Parliamentary Secretaries in Article 31, you find that the President, acting in accordance with the advice of the Prime Minister, may by instrument under the public seal, appoint Parliamentary Secretaries. And it stops with that. It is "Parliamentary Secretaries from ,among the Members of Parliament". Then you have a number of other Articles following that, and I cannot find any Article which gives the President or the Prime Minister the power to appoint a Political Secretary. So would you please refer us to the Article in the Constitution?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson, when he first rose, said that he could not find any reference to the term "Political Secretary" in the Constitution. He obviously has not looked carefully. If he looks at Article 2, Clause (5), the Constitution has expressly recognized the office of Political Secretary, because it says:

    'For the purposes of this Constitution, a person shall not be considered as holding a public office or an office of profit by reason of the fact that he is in receipt of any remuneration or allowances ... in respect of his tenure of the office of President, Vice-President, Prime Minister, Chief Justice, Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Minister, Parliamentary Secretary, Political Secretary...'.

    So he misled the House when he said that the Constitution makes no reference to Political Secretary.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, that Article 2 is an interpretation Article. Before you can appoint anyone, there must be an

Column: 1270

express power of appointment. Surely, the Minister for Home Affairs, who was at one time a Professor of Law, must know this. Where is the express power of appointment of Political Secretaries? Do not refer us to the Interpretation section.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a very strange concept in Constitutional law to say that every person who is appointed in the public service in Singapore or political service in Singapore must be referred to in the Constitution. There are many designations, many titles of people who are employed.

    The point that the Member for Anson made when he first rose was that he could not find any reference in the Constitution to Political Secretary, and I have pointed out that the Constitution has expressly taken recognition of the office of Political Secretary.

    As to the details of the appointment, there are many appointments in each Ministry - Minister, Minister of State, Parliamentary Secretary, Permanent Secretary, Deputy Secretary, down to the clerk, the peon and so on. Do all these appointments require special authorization in the Constitution? I would like to know where is there this rule that all these appointments must be specifically named in the Constitution. Where is the authority for that proposition?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Will the Minister concede, without any equivocation now, that there is no power in the Constitution giving the Prime Minister or the President the power to appoint a Political Secretary? There is, of course, in what he has referred to, in the Interpretation section, the word "Political Secretary". But I repeat, "Where is the power of appointment of Political Secretaries to be found in the Constitution?" You will not find it. This was raised by the Member for Farrer Park in 1959 and it was not answered. Now, I say that every political appointment must find an enabling provision in the Constitution - the power to appoint to that political post. And that is why you find it in the Constitution that the President shall appoint the Prime Minister and that he shall appoint Ministers, acting in accordance with the Prime Minister's advice. Then you go on to Parliamentary

Column: 1271

Secretaries. That is in the section dealing with the Executive. Do you find anything about Political Secretaries in the Executive appointments?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I admitted just now I am no expert in law, but I believe that we run a system that is fair and open and can be challenged by anyone in Parliament and outside, in the court. The appointment of Political Secretary is not a new appointment. Political Secretaries have been appointed for years and, in my layman's approach, if there has been any wrongdoing in the appointment of Political Secretaries, that should have been challenged in court long ago by the Member for Anson when he was outside this House.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: We get the stock reply from Government Ministers, "Why don't you go and challenge it in a court of law?"

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Why didn't you?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Well, I am challenging it here in Parliament. And Parliament is the High Court of Parliament. [Laughter]. Well, I am afraid people who do not know anything about Parliamentary tradition will obviously laugh. But it is the High Court of Parliament. Anyone will tell you. And I am challenging it here. I say this is an abuse of public funds.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have asked him, where does he get this legal proposition that every appointment must be authorized by the Constitution? The appointments which he referred to (Ministers, Parliamentary Secretaries) are provided for in the Constitution. Now he wants all other appointments to be expressly provided for in the Constitution. But the point is that every year, in this Parliament, the Minister for Finance presents the Budget which expressly provides for the appointments of Political Secretaries. If Parliament found that that provision was unauthorized, Parliament would reject it. Parliament has the power to query such provisions -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am afraid it is not.

     Prof. Jayakumar: - but not on the basis of a Constitutional issue. And as the First Deputy Prime Minister has pointed out, if

Column: 1272

he really feels strongly that a grave issue of the Constitution has arisen, that the Constitution has been violated, it is a legal issue which has to be remedied not by Parliament but must be remedied by reference to the courts which, under our Constitutional system, are the proper body to pronounce on the legal interpretation of the Constitution. The legal interpretation of the Constitution is not what the Member for Anson says that it is. But it is what the court pronounces them to be.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the fact that ii has not been raised before does not mean that it cannot be raised today. And I am raising it today. The Minister for Home Affairs asks: what is this principle that says that there must be a provision somewhere for every appointment?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Quote chapter and verse.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Well, the Minister for Home Affairs must know that every public office appointment is provided for by Staute. Does he not know that?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Anson is challenging the constitutionality or otherwise of the appointment of Political Secretaries, as my colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs, has pointed out, the proper place to challenge this is outside, in the court, for a proper legal interpretation of the Constitution.

     The Chairman: Will you withdraw your amendment, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am not withdrawing my amendment, Sir.

    Question put, "That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead UA-01 of the Main Estimates."

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I call for a division?
